body: A restaurant owner contemplates moving into a smaller space. A bicycle manufacturer lays off five workers. A car salesman postpones retirement. In October, The New York Times began tracking how six small businesses were handling the recession. The holiday season seems to have provided little relief: Layoffs, shorter hours and struggles to pay bills
title: A Pinch Becomes a Squeeze

body: LANDMARK DISTRICT HOUSE $1,750,000 BROOKLYN: 445 East 19th Street, Ditmas Park A French Norman house with five bedrooms, four full baths and two half baths, built in 1931 by Arthur Ebinger, founder of Ebinger's Bakery. The house has three wood-burning fireplaces and a landscaped garden with a pond. Alexandra Reddish, Mary Kay Gallagher Real Estate
title: ON THE MARKET

body: IT took Ali Newman and Desmond Curran two tries to sell their two-bedroom one-bath co-op in Kensington, Brooklyn. The first try was in February 2007. They listed the apartment at $335,000 -- they had paid $190,000 for it in 2005 -- and one month later accepted an offer of $330,000. But the deal fell apart. Very shortly after that, Ms. Newman
title: THE SELL; Ax the Drapes; Move the Stuff

body: AROUND TOWN ICE SKATING IN NEW YORK The weather can't seem to make up its mind -- vacillating between the mid-60s one week and snow the next -- but the calendar doesn't lie: we're in the post-Daylight Saving Time zone, during which it's impossible to deny the approach of winter. So you may as well give in, bundle up and head outdoors. This year
title: Spare Times

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites BARTOW-PELL MANSION, 895 Shore Road North, Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx. Saturday at noon, a workshop in making harvest-themed holiday centerpieces out of natural materials; $45 ($30 for members), including materials. Reservations required: (718) 885-1461. Tour hours: Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 4 p.m.;
title: Spare Times

body: Opening This Week APERITIVO Wood-burning ovens will fire up on Nov. 19 for pizzas of varied geometry and toppings. There is a broader Italian menu: 780 Third Avenue (48th Street), (212) 758-9402. B. title: Off the Menu

body: A butcher's longtime customers stop paying their bills. A building contractor has half as many jobs as he did a year ago. A restaurant owner considers sharing space to stay afloat. Steadily, inexorably, the fallout from Wall Street's layoffs and the credit crisis is trickling down to small businesses across the region. Over the coming months, The
title: Small Businesses in a Financial Hurricane

body: Mr. Villasante, 46, owner of V & V Construction in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, immigrated from Uruguay in 1986. He has been in business for 17 years, running a small contracting firm that specializes in painting and home renovations. He typically employs nine workers during the busy months. But with half as many jobs as he had last year, he has been
title: Region's Small Businesses in Path of a Financial Hurricane

author: E-mail: dwyer@nytimes.com
body: Cocking her head toward the door, Priscilla Becker showed how she tried to hear any signs of life inside Apartment 2K. ''I was listening for the dog,'' she said. Not a sound. In the six months she had lived in the building, Ms. Becker had seen the man in Apartment 2K exactly twice. Both times he was walking a long-haired little dog. There had been
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; In Apt. 2K, A Mystery Unresolved

title: ON THE MARKET; Ditmas Park Co-op

author: E-mail: greenfield@nytimes.com
body: SIX years ago, Yvette Folk made a real estate purchase that not everyone in her life could see the value in. ''My sister called my father to say that I had lost my mind,'' said Ms. Folk, 52, describing the offending apartment: a one-bedroom co-op in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, on Albemarle Road. The property had sat vacant for two years after the owner
title: THE SELL; When It's Not Enough Just to Cut the Price

body: NEW YORKERS love to complain about television or film crews that descend on their neighborhoods, gobbling up parking spaces, crowding the sidewalks and generally disrupting daily life. But some people aren't complaining. They are the ones who are renting their apartments and houses to those crews, and making $500 to $10,000 a day, depending on the
title: Lights! Camera! Ka-Ching!

body: An article and an accompanying list last Wednesday about Brooklyn restaurants that have involved the entrepreneurs Alan Harding and Jim Mamary misstated the name of one Mr. Harding opened in Red Hook and the year it opened, and erroneously included one item on its menu. The restaurant was The Old Pioneer, not Pioneer Bar-B-Que; it opened in 2004,
title: Correction: 'Restless Pioneers, Seeding Brooklyn'

body: WITH a trunk full of cod, brisket, blackberries, arugula and antifreeze, Alan Harding drives down Smith Street, past American Apparel, past the Michelin-starred restaurant Saul and past Patois, the bistro he helped open 11 years ago. Back then the neighborhood was a more likely destination for drug deals than dinner. Patois, where he was the chef,
title: Restless Pioneers, Seeding Brooklyn

body: Late one night, shortly after Kai Lui and his wife, Laura Campbell-Lui, moved into their Queen Anne-style house in Midwood, Brooklyn, she shook him awake, insisting that she heard intruders. Mr. Lui went to investigate and discovered noises coming from the fourth-floor attic. He called the police. ''They had their weapons drawn,'' said Mr. Lui, a
title: The City's Latest Real Estate Fight: Humans Against Raccoons

body: Smoke wafted from grills and burners along the grassy patches on the southern edge of Brooklyn's Prospect Park on Sunday, carrying the scents of homelands near and far. From under a grove of trees came the tartness of cactus leaves known in Mexico as nopales. From under a green-and-white tent, the sweetness of banan peze, Haiti's fried plantains.
title: For America's Birthday, Fire Up the Grill, but Hold the Hot Dogs and Potato Salad

body: Address: 536 East 19th Street, between Ditmas and Newkirk Avenues. The Property: This three-story 1910 frame house with seven bedrooms and two and a half baths has been on the market for four months and was just reduced from $1.1 million. While it needs new appliances and a cosmetic face-lift, the mechanicals are in good shape and the bathrooms
title: BUY OF THE WEEK/DITMAS PARK, BROOKLYN

body: A three-story 1910 frame house in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, part of Victorian Flatbush.
title: Buy of the Week: July 4, 2008

body: BARS CLOVER CLUB 210 Smith Street (Baltic Street), Boerum Hill, Brooklyn; (718) 855-7939. The more serious the cocktail the more fun the night out: this is the guiding principle of the Clover Club, a Smith Street bar that serves what are now known as pre-Prohibition drinks, a professorial assortment of fizzes, smashes, swizzles and sours. If the
title: DINING BRIEFS; Dining Briefs

body: Alana Vegter spent a year teaching band to middle school students in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn.
title: Master Class

body: It was just after dawn when Theo Otibu began prowling Ditmas Park in Brooklyn in his unmarked Sanitation Department car. He scanned the sidewalk for an elusive prey, one known only by the droppings of its best friend: the dog owner who does not scoop. He spotted a woman in a long black coat leading a small white dog. Mr. Otibu, who has been a
title: Scoop It Up or Pay: On Patrol With Enforcers of the Dog Law

body: LAST winter, Dan Gordon decided that his $1,600-a-month rental in Park Slope, Brooklyn, needed a paint job. So he called his landlord. The conversation turned from painting to moving. Because of changes stemming from a death in the family, the landlord intended to move in. After five years, Mr. Gordon would have to leave. His parlor floor
title: THE HUNT; A Handyman's Special

body: DITMAS PARK DUPLEX $545,000 BROOKLYN: 415 Argyle Road (near Cortelyou Road), #20 A two-bedroom two-bath co-op in a 105-unit 1960s brick building. Jan Rosenberg, Brooklyn Hearth Realty (347) 446-9688, www.brooklynhearth.com MAINTENANCE: $1,066 a month PROS: Because the bedrooms are upstairs and the downstairs living space opens onto a street-front
title: ON THE MARKET; ON THE MARKET

body: FOR Maggie Tobin and Bob Mason, the last straw in Park Slope was the parking. The couple, who have two young children, lived there for eight years and loved being near Prospect Park and surrounded by friends. But when the time came to buy, they wanted more space and found the prices too high, and they decided they could also live without the ritual
title: LIVING IN KENSINGTON, BROOKLYN; Name From London, People From Everywhere

body: ARIELLE GREEN, a publicist in Manhattan, knows what most of her friends earn, whether it is $28,000 a year or $100,000. And she does not seem particularly shy about disclosing her income ($30,000 a year, plus overtime). At 22, Ms. Green, like her friends, is less afraid to flirt with what many over 35 consider the last taboo in American life:
title: Not-So-Personal Finance

body: DITMAS PARK DOUBLE HOUSE $1,495,000 BROOKLYN: 1208 Beverley Road (between Westminster and Argyle Roads) A 1910 Dutch colonial with mirror-image 2,300-square-foot houses, identical entrances, separate utilities and shared backyard. The owner's triplex has four bedrooms, two and a half baths and a deck; the adjoining unit, now a rental, has six
title: ON THE MARKET; Ditmas Park Double House

body: THERE was great excitement last fall in the part of Brooklyn known affectionately as Victorian Flatbush when the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission recommended that Midwood Park and Fiske Terrace, two neighborhoods within this network of communities south of Prospect Park, be designated a historic district. On Tuesday, five months after the
title: VICTORIAN FLATBUSH; Peaked Roofs, Crossed Fingers

title: ON THE MARKET; Ditmas Park Co-op

body: Usually, it is the harsh yellow of the crime scene tape that catches the eye, its cold, crisp snap in the wind a universally understood sign of recent unpleasantness. But at the corner of Newkirk Avenue and Argyle Road in Brooklyn, amid countless bodegas and Laundromats and Chinese takeout joints, it was not the yellow tape alone that drew
title: DITMAS PARK JOURNAL; Betting on Cuisine to Marginalize Crime
